newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus to buy 180,000 T raw sugar in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Belarus to buy 180,000 T raw sugar in 1997.

text.p: Belarus will buy 180,000 tonnes of raw sugar in 1997 against 150,000 in 1996, Deputy Agriculture Minister Ivan Shakolo said on Tuesday.
"We have already received 42,000 tonnes of raws from Argentina. Today we are holding talks with Cuba about the possibility of trading raws for fertilisers," Shakolo told a news conference.
Belarus has annual domestic refined sugar needs of about 300,000 tonnes.

Shakolo said Belarus held talks with Ukrainian officials last week about imposing a quota on refined sugar imports in 1997. He said he expected to have an official announcement on the matter some time next month.
"The market has to be civilised. Because of inflows of cheap Ukrainian sugar last year we were forced to stop our own production and bring sanctions against imports," he said.
Ukraine has been a traditional sugar supplier to Belarus and Russia. Russia has said it will levy a 25 percent duty on Ukrainian sugar imports next month.
The duty is expected to replace an earlier plan to impose an import quota of 1.5 million tonnes on all white sugar imports into Russia in 1997 - including 1.15 million tonnes for Ukraine.
Belarus has also imposed a 25 percent duty on white sugar imports, Shakolo added.
But last month President Alexander Lukashenko removed the duty to make way for imports of 30,000 tonnes from Ukraine to meet domestic needs.
Shakolo said Belarus planned to strike a deal with Germany next month to modernise its four refineries.
"In the future we hope to completely secure the needs of our republic in terms of white sugar production from our own sugar beets," he said.
The Belarus sugar beet harvest was one million tonnes in 1996 after 1.14 million tonnes in 1995.
